facts.text: Lands belonging to appellants: survey Nos. 281/2, 339/1 to 8 and 338/1 to 3, situate at a short distance from Vijayawada, alongside Vijayawada-Eluru Road.
Land Acquisition Officer fixed Rs. 3,500 per acre for first two survey Nos. and Rs. 4,000 per acre for survey No. 338.
Disputes regarding entitlement to compensation for survey No. 339/1 to 3; Land Acquisition Officer made reference to Court under s.30 for apportionment.
Six appellants did not accept award, made applications under s.18 within time for reference on quantum of compensation; no reference made by LAO for quantum.
Subordinate Judge, Vijayawada granted uniform rate of Rs. 10,000 per acre for all survey numbers.
Matter proceeded before Subordinate Judge on footing that reference included quantum, no objection by State.
Andhra Pradesh High Court in Appeal Suit No. 489 of 1954 reduced compensation; State raised jurisdiction plea, High Court negatived it.
Sale deeds filed: Exs. A1 to A4 by State, B1 to B3 by appellants.
High Court rejected A1,A2,B1,B2,B3; accepted A3,A4; awarded Rs.4500/acre.

legal_issues.text: Whether the Court had jurisdiction to determine the quantum of compensation in absence of reference by Land Acquisition Officer under s.18, when reference under s.30 was only for apportionment.
What is the market value of the acquired lands for compensation.

petitioner_arguments.text: State waived objection to jurisdiction by not raising it before Subordinate Judge; defect waivable as not inherent lack of jurisdiction.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Venkata Krishnayya Garu v. Secretary of State

petitioner_arguments.text: Compensation should be Rs.10,000/acre based on sale deeds B1,B2,B3 showing higher rates.
Lands in A3,A4 had no direct road access, so lower value not comparable.

respondent_arguments.text: Court lacked inherent jurisdiction without reference under s.18 for quantum; cannot go behind LAO award; no waiver possible.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Sections 12,18,19,21,30 Land Acquisition Act; Nusserwanjee Pestonjee v. Meer Mynoodeen Khan; Alderson v. Palliser; Seth Badri Prasad v. Seth Nagarmal

respondent_arguments.text: Compensation at Rs.4,500/acre based on A3,A4; reject appellants' sale deeds as ante-dated, post-notification, distant, small extent.

court_reasoning.text: Jurisdiction arises solely on reference by Collector under s.18/19; s.30 reference for apportionment does not cover quantum; inherent lack of jurisdiction, not waivable.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Universal principle: statutory jurisdiction terms must be complied with; State remiss but cannot take advantage, yet jurisdiction absent.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished Venkata Krishnayya: there was a reference, albeit erroneous.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No reference at all here for quantum.

court_reasoning.text: On merits, High Court correctly rejected A1,A2 (pre-notification, distant), B1,B2,B3 (ante-dated, post-notification, distant/small); accepted A3,A4 at Rs.4500/acre reasonable for agricultural land with access via unsold portion.

holdings.text: Court had no jurisdiction to determine amount of compensation absent reference under s.18.
Even on merits, Rs.4,500 per acre appropriate.

precedents_cited.case_name: Nusserwanjee Pestonjee Ors. v. Meer Mynoodeen Khan Wullud Meer Sudroodeen Khan Bahadoor
precedents_cited.relevance: Statutory jurisdiction only on specified terms; non-compliance means no jurisdiction.
Want of jurisdiction on face of proceedings cannot be waived.

precedents_cited.case_name: Seth Badri Prasad Ors. v. Seth Nagarmal and Ors.
precedents_cited.relevance: Illegality apparent on face can be raised even if not pleaded below.

precedents_cited.case_name: Venkata Krishnayya Garu v. Secretary of State
precedents_cited.relevance: Reference made though erroneous; here no reference at all.

statutes_cited.name: Land Acquisition Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs finality of award, applications for reference, scope of court proceedings, apportionment references.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed on ground of lack of jurisdiction to determine quantum; on merits, no interference with High Court's reduction to Rs.4,500 per acre warranted.

key_quotes.text: "This is not a kind of plea which the State ought at all to have taken. Quite clearly applications objecting to the rates... were taken in time..."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Court's disapproval of State's technical plea despite LAO's remissness.

key_quotes.text: "wherever jurisdiction is given by a statute... those terms should be complied with... if they are not complied with the jurisdiction does not arise."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core principle affirming lack of inherent jurisdiction.
